pros:
Friendly colleagues. 
Nice coffee. 
That’s all.
cons:
I have endless cons of Oracle Singapore.

The very first and most irritating thing is extremely useless and political HR team. Selfish to the core. All about themselves. I recalled one of them said “I wanted to be in sales, gain power and money”.

Secondly, I joined less than a year, now I’m seeing them chopping off existing headcount, and all hiring freeze. Poor talent retention, and obvious cronyism.

Their cloud solution needs tremendous improvement. 
I’m not surprised looking at their poor cloud penetration and performance. Literally less than 10% of my customers even asking about Oracle Cloud. My friends in the similar industry said the same. 

Lack of clear and proven strategy. Fire your existing HR TEAM, so the new ones able to find and recruit the right talent. Almost non existence of marketing campaign with clear messaging. 

Leaders are incompetent. Many are yes man or yes woman. Bring them along to meet customer, they are mumbling gibberish topics. Customers are discombobulated. 

If any of you thinking of joining them, think twice. Their only hope is the on-premise licenses, unfortunately no one is focusing that.

Doom day.

pros: There are pockets of great culture within different teams, and different lines of business. The training is second to none, and they provide you with so much material. It's not difficult to get recognition if you show your efforts of collaboration and networking throughout the company. Benefits and commission is structure is very good - if you negotiate well for it before you get the job offer. Quarterly team recognitions which helps boost team morale.
cons: It's stagnated professional development - when you get a job, expect to be in the same role and same pay for a minimum of 3 years unless you threaten to leave (and even then you need to prove that you are invaluable). Managers do provide support, but you need to ensure that you are holding them accountable as well. Very process driven, so it can take weeks to get something done. The brand perception is an outdated grandfather's company, but marketing is trying to change that (which is a feat in itself).

pros: Stability - it takes a long time for any change or innovation to happen so if you're after a stable job that operates like clockwork then you can try your hand at Oracle.
cons:
Everything is about process, not in the way of trying to make things more efficient but red tape for administrative justification. You will be exhausted by having 2 jobs, your actual day job and the job of navigating internal politics. 

Oracle is not a company that looks out for its employees. There is a lot of talk about it where the management team do hurrah sessions to pat each other on the back, but execution is weak.

review_title: When performance does not equate to remuneration gain.
pros: Access to some of the smartest people in the industry, cutting edge technology, working for a company that is helping business change the world for the better
cons:
Change is constant, and sometimes to the detriment of the business as teams interpret the strategy differently and run and operate in different directions. Internal Line of business competition is Oracle's biggest inhibitor.
Career progression can be hindered, new joiners tend to be paid more than legacy employees because of Oracle's limited payrise policies creating large remuneration gaps.
Anecdotally - if you want a pay rise, leave Oracle and return in 12 months time.

review_title: Great quality of work, not so great work life balance!
pros:
This review is only for Oracle Consulting, Singapore.

Pros:
* Get to work on some of the largest and more complicated engagements.
* Regional exposure across ASEAN.
* Hands off management style giving significant freedom
* Excellent peers - mostly senior, subject matter experts in their domains.
cons:
* Consultants required to don multiple hats, which gives great learning and exposure but can take a toll on work life balance.
* Limited career planning - you need to take charge of your career, network and find avenues to grow. This can be challenging for some.

You're just a number on a spreadsheet - dont take it personally.

review_title: Oracle is good for first 3 years then you should switch (unless you are in sales)
pros: Excellent products, can provide end-to-end solutions, very aggressive in sales (so as pre-sales you learn things quickly), lots of talented resources to learn from, if you work hard you get recognition. As pre-sales there is lot to learn and no one will stop you from learning new things and starting the pre-sales activities on your own. Oracle will help generously for external training and certifications (full reimbursement). work from home, flexible timing, when you travel you always stay in 5-star hotels and their is no TA/DA (so expenses are all paid via corporate credit card and there is no limit for food bills ). Good compensation for sales guys
cons:
negotiate well when you join oracle because salary wont increase every year, been in Oracle for 6 years, achieved 150% of KPIs fr past 3 years, but no pay  raise. Only way you can get a pay-raise is after you get a job outside and based on offer letter, HR and Management will match the salary (I dont support this method)
Politics is there, need to know the right people to get promotions (btw promotions doesn't necessarily increase your salary). Manager can tell you that his own salary has not increase so how can he help you ? huh...
Since its a sales-driven org, above mentioned cons dont apply to sales team. they can get their salary raised easily (they have solid numbers to show from yearly quota achievement etc). Pre-sales, even though is the most important dept, dont get good treatment.

review_title: OK but watch out after a few years..
pros: It's a huge company, generally there's a lot of runway for projects/initiatives so less work pressure. Oracle has offerings across pretty much the entire IT stack, this means an entire solution can be offered to customers.
cons:
Lots of politics, if you're not visible 1-2 (sales) tiers above your direct manager, your career will stagnate. You are pretty much tied to whatever compensation you can negotiate coming in, because annual increases are nonexistent to minimal.  The only sure-fire way to get a decent increment is by showing your manager a competing offer.  If your manager wants to retain you, Oracle will counter-offer.  I experienced this, the counter-offer was in fact better than the competing offer, but I felt that I had to decline.

It pretty much sucks that long-term employees (I was there 9 years) suffer compensation-wise and need to resort to seeking outside offers, while new hires come in at significantly higher levels (since the median acquisition cost increases every year) but I understand this is common in the industry.

cons: HR is the biggest conmen. They con you into the job, press down on your pay, make you join the company with all the empty promises. Upon joining, many employees feel that they have been cheated into the job, either from the pay perspective, or the role that they signed up for. Changes happen in Oracle every quarter. Do not join if you can’t keep up with that. They fire and hire easily and mercilessly. They can claw back your commission anytime after your successfully close deals. So if you happen to close big deals, just take the money and leave. Before they somehow find some lame excuse and reason to claw back your hard earned money.

pros: Multi-cultural, flexible working hours, friendly colleagues depended on your team. If you are driven and proactive, there are plenty of opportunities.

pros:
-Oracle have one of the most comprehensive technology suite in planet, for someone who is keen into learning tons of stuffs in one company, this can be a good place
-US culture hence as long you delivers your job no one really cares when/where you work[unless you're unlucky to have micro manager]
-Sales is KING here, so yes good place if you(sales) want things in your way.
-Decent benefits, but nothing much to brag about
-There are some really brilliant, friendly, talented, and great people here, though it getting much rare nowadays because they have better opportunities.
-You can/should demand very very awesome pay if you coming from competitors as long you know how negotiate well. Make sure you do this because you know what you will be facing and NO INCREMENT for years to come whatever role you are.
-Everything is negotiable in Oracle, from promotion/increment/territory change, etc. So pray hard you have a good manager and negotiate hard. 
-Empowered employee is true here because from day 1 to last day is SELF-SERVICE culture including setting up/formatting your laptop
cons:
-Hire and Fire Culture: Restructuring is such a norm that you're numb of it. Every 6 months a minor and 1.5-2 years massive earthquake. For front liners, you literally wouldn't be able to focus because the top mgmt  doesn't have a long term strategy at all. Worse, the top mgmt make it like experiment. They could set up a new group(like Oracle Digital) and demand the current workforce to relocate. If you don't want to relocate, then technically you just have to leave. So technically you see in paper Oracle seems growing but that's big lie, because they indirectly lay off huge team and hire people in. After 1.5 years, the OD team get killed again. Gotcha!

-Acquire and Kill strategy: If you can't win, you acquire, Oracle is genius in this space. Nothing wrong about acquisition, but the problem is when you killed it. Think of best of breed at the time like JAVA, PeopleSoft, JDE, Siebel, and many more. Where are they now? They are DEAD! This leave customer who invest millions of dollars into product and overnight Oracle tell(force) you to move to cloud which is not apple to apple. Customers(esp FSI/Telco) literally HATES Oracle and pity frontliners gonna deal with FIRE and sell them cloud while executives hide behind them. Also, good talent leave with knowledge, the new people doesn't know how to sell essence of solid product and acquired BEST products are slowly becoming irrelevant as time goes.

-Ego Empire: You may heard of Thomas Kurian news. That's how it works in Oracle. No customer in market see Oracle as leader in cloud as compared to AWS/SFDC/WD. But top mgmt/Larry just doesn't want to recognize it, why should they anyway(high pay and retiring). The reason Oracle is more cost effective is simply they mark up prices on AWS platform. Also product never really develop for customer but more for their own ideas.

-Good people are not appreciated here: I've seen loyal, humble, hardworking, nice, and talented people who delivers but just treated cruelly, and the bullies and smokers climbing the stairs because they know sell themselves and squeeze others. That's why more good people left and more leeches stays on Oracle.

pros: Although OFSS is totally not the real "Oracle", you also can write it on your resume. I think it's quite a good experience to do Java development in "Oracle" when you are applying other software development jobs.

Manager is rude, the company culture is bad.

review_title: Downhill journey in Primesourcing, don't join Primesourcing LoB in Oracle.

pros: BIg Shop that carries all products under one roof, from database to middleware to applications to hardware.  Even own consulting arm that implements the more complex projects.

pros: Very chill company, colleagues are nice, managers are nice. cons: Pay increment is little or almost non-existence. Other than that, i can't think of anything else.

review_title: Great benefits, good people, slow innovation, no raises
job_title: Technical Analyst III (Support) in Denver, CO
pros: Every group/division can be different in how they treat their employees, but I'd say overall there is very good atmosphere of trust and fairness. There is a strong focus on education, and they reimburse for outside classes taken (Up to 5k/year I think). Benefits are good, and I'd say quite competitive in the market. Good 401K matching (they'll contribute a max of 3% of your 6% or greater). Free drinks in the breakroom. Flexibility to work from home at times. (If you live 50+ miles away from an office you can work full-time from home...policy).
cons: They don't try to make the workplace anything special (maybe a pool table and arcade game are cliche or gimmicky?). In the 10 years I've worked there, they've given 2 measly %1 cost of living raises (this is the same with most everyone I've spoken to, some don't get any raises). You will not get a substantial raise ever, unless you leave then get rehired on (they will not match offers, better to leave). New employees that you train will make 10 - 20K more than you several years after you hire on (not just me, they do this to all tenured employees). They will give these untrained, less experienced people higher titles (again this is done to everyone not just me). You learn pretty quickly that you're dispensable. The company has billions in cash and they don't re-invest in their employees, just in acquiring new companies and hiring new people that know nothing that you get to train.

job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: Career growth opportunities: Oracle is a large, established company with many job functions and departments, which provides employees with the chance to advance their careers. Competitive compensation and benefits: Oracle is known for offering competitive salaries, bonuses, and benefits packages to its employees. Cutting-edge technology: As a technology company, Oracle provides its employees with exposure to and experience with the latest and greatest in technology. Global presence: With offices and operations around the world, working at Oracle offers the opportunity to work on a global scale and interact with people from diverse cultures and backgrounds. Work-life balance: Oracle is committed to creating a positive work-life balance for its employees, offering flexible work arrangements and resources to help manage work and personal responsibilities.
cons: Bureaucracy: As a large company, Oracle can be bureaucratic and slow to make decisions, which can be frustrating for employees who want to see immediate results. High pressure environment: Oracle is a demanding workplace, with high expectations for performance and a fast-paced work environment. Limited creativity: Some employees may find that their work at Oracle is more focused on maintenance and implementation of existing products, rather than on innovation and creating new solutions.

review_title: Benefits are Amazing, but Office Politics is King
pros: Oracle NetSuite has phenomenal employee benefits and top-tier training opportunities and resources for product knowledge for employees. The staff appears to be more laid-back than traditional corporate companies: most people introduce themselves casually and refer to everyone by their first names. There is a strong community- and team-based structure and people are quick to respond to Slack messages and are often very friendly.
cons: During my time training, a consultant who had been in the role for roughly six months explained that, despite the friendly corporate culture, there was a much higher turnover rate for NetSuite consultants than I expected. Once I graduated training, I saw it happen in real-time: within the first year of working there, four to five team members on projects that I was staffed on left NetSuite to work for NetSuite Partner or Alliance companies in the same role. There were even more that did the same that I had connected with on LinkedIn or that I heard about from other coworkers. I wish that, during interviews/training/onboarding, there was more emphasis put on the necessity to network with Project Managers, Delivery Leads, etc, and office politics in general in order to get put on projects to maintain utilization performance levels and the importance of utilization. Without connections to PMs, you are very unlikely to get put on projects and get the experience that PMs and DLs are looking for in staffing larger projects for career growth; so, you have to job-hunt within the job to maintain performance levels and ensure you're in a position to get promoted. I also wish there was more transparency regarding the process of completing a horizontal shift into a role in another department instead of the emphasis that they put on vertical shifts in the same role or department. They also appear to be making moves to bring their employees back to the office, specifically in Sales roles. Usually, when co-workers stated that they were in the office while on Zoom calls, the background would be quite noisy, which seems a bit counter-productive for a job that would be meeting with most customers via Zoom anyway.

review_title: Oracle NetSuite is a Great Place to Start Your Career
pros: The NetSuite BDR program is a great way to start a sales career. Unlike other BDR/SDR programs, it's consistently just a 10-14 month time as a BDR before being eligible to promote into a quota-bearing sales role. Very fast track to a lucrative early career in sales. The Account Management team is a high-performing team full of great managers who want to win, empower reps, and empower customers. In general, I like most of the people I work with at Oracle NetSuite and the Employee Resource Groups have made a difference in my sense of belonging and my network at Oracle. Remote/Hybrid work has been a huge advantage and made a difference in my ability to be productive while on the clock, and enjoy work/life balance.
cons: NetSuite being a unit of Oracle means we experience the typical frustrations of working for a gigantic corporation. There are lots of processes and procedures in place which sometimes slow things down. Account Managers sometimes spend more time than we'd like to focusing on customer concerns rather than focusing on selling. This is because there is not a built-out/dedicated CSM program across the existing customer base.

review_title: Going Through Changes, But Could Be Good Depending On Your Team
job_title: Principal Project Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Some parts of the company have unlimited PTO Work-life balance can be good D&I efforts through their Employee Readiness Groups are active and supportive Good Benefits with extra perks like wifi reimbursement (only up to $50 though)
cons: Pay is on the lower side, especially if you're non-OCI Little opportunity for pay raises. You might get a tiny merit raise bump, and maybe even some RSUs. But your best bet is to negotiate your salary right from jump when you first get an offer here. It'll probably become a non-competitive salary after a few years, but by then you should either move up or move out of the company. As reported by the headlines, Oracle has had rolling layoffs throughout the company since this summer (of 2022). It has tanked morale and made it much more difficult to get some things done because we still have the same amount of work but even fewer people to do it all. Certain parts of the company there's been RIFs, now there's attrition and there's no way to backfill them. People are definitely feeling the squeeze. Honestly, things aren't looking so great from here.

review_title: OCI Is THE Place to be right now
pros:
- Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, and my division (Cloud Venture) specifically, is RED HOT right now 
- Great platform with a ton of potential to grab market share
 - matches or exceeds the competition in all of the important areas 
- No dealing with budget objections, we're almost always the cheapest option - by a wide margin 
-Current macro environment, which has hurt most SaaS sellers, is actually a huge benefit to us as companies are looking to slash IT costs 
- Almost every company needs a cloud services provider! 
- Commission potential is excellent in most territories, many reps (including myself) have a real opportunity to hit 1.5 or 2x their OTE. A lot of reps are making serious money right now or will be soon. 
- Nice SPIF bonuses that are pretty easy to obtain 
- A lot of great managers - my manager is incredible and others seem great as well. Seem to be truly bad first-line managers around.
cons:
- Internal systems are a drag at times, though they're getting better. Can't transfer the knowledge you've built up using tools like Salesforce, Outreach or Salesloft, we don't use any of that stuff 
- SDR organization (we call them BDCs) is god awful and most reps aren't getting a ton of opportunities outside of their own prospecting 
-Solutions engineers are hit or miss, though a handful are exceptional

review_title: Revolving door of leadership, high rate of product/service issues make the role more challenging
pros: Very flexible in terms of your hours; hit your quota and you are off the hook for the quarter. Some products have very high satisfaction rates (Eloqua, Maxymiser, most of the marketing suite) which makes the renewal conversations much, much easier.
cons: A lot of bureaucracy and hoops to jump through to get deals out the door. Long lead times to coordinate with procurement, provisioning, and Oracle legal to sort out customers' more complex contract-related questions. It can lead to your deals pushing into the next quarter or fiscal year. Also, very, VERY unclear bonus structure and low payouts. I suppose that is a tradeoff for not having to really grind like a traditional outside sales role does. Also a high degree of leadership turnover - lot of deck chair rearranging before they realize that the organization is kind of a mess and they work to get promoted into another organization.

review_title: Good place to start your career, not a long term option
pros: Some of the managers I've had in my almost 5 years at Oracle have been some of the best managers I've had. That being said, your experience will vary based on your manager/senior management. The teammates I had on various projects were hands down some of the smartest, nicest people I've ever met. Work/life balance is also incredible.
cons: Others have said it, but imo this is the biggest con of working at this company -- you will NOT receive a raise likely ever. New hires will start at a significantly higher salary than you. Despite incredible performance reviews or customer feedback, it will be pulling teeth to get even a 5% increase. Management will not try to match or counter any other offers you have, and in my experience will become exceedingly bitter and spiteful once you decide to leave the company. There is an obvious lack of support to promote within and do what's needed to keep good employees.

review_title: Can be great / Can be horrible - depends on your leadership
pros: Great enterprise applications and platform hosting strategy. Smart people. Good benefits. It can be amazing, depending on the organization's leadership. Oracle is very siloed, so one group can be great and another can be horrible, even in the same division.
cons: The company is very shareholder centric, which means every penny is watched and decisions on the stock price will always take precedence over doing the right thing for employees. As a stockholder, it's great, as an employee, you can go 5-10 years without a raise. The company has gotten rid of all employee-building events and uses rolling lay-offs as a management tool to meet quarterly margin goals. If you do get laid off, expect one of the worst severance packages in the industry. The CEO is very operations-focused. You'll rarely hear any top-line messaging or communications from her.

pros: Obviously it’s a fantastic company, especially  if you have a Mgr from Australia. Fantastic benefits, flexibility if you need it, the best products, great local leaders. If you are driven, you will do fantastic with commission. You just won’t be managed very well especially if your manager is overseas, it’s a little abusive.
cons: Many of the senior managers are located in India or SG. There is very little protection if you’re a female and zero support and  HR won’t help., You think they will but as soon as you put in a complaint (which they encourage you to do) , they also turn back on you. So my advice is to do your best, do not go to HR if you feel you are being abused. Either stay or leave xx and please look after your mental health.. to all the females struggling, you’re doing amazing! You’re up against all of these men, constantly. Don’t forget how great you’re doing, and don’t let one of them knock your confidence.

cons: exploitation, crazy work expectations, micromanagement harassment (manager would call us at 6 am or 9:30 pm, he didn’t care our schedule was 8-5 M-F, oh yes you guessed it he would call on the weekends too). We had 2 mandatory zoom calls at 8 am and  4/4:30) besides the 3-5 calls we would have with costumers scheduled last minute or to discuss a billing issue. No matter how hard I worked management was not happy and kept adding more and more work. Many people quit so management decided to add to my work load Colombia, Ecuador, Chile, besides Peru’s billing which was the roll I was hired for. Long story short, they wanted me to do the work or 4-5 people without extra pay, moreover; they never payed me over time even though I worked passed 5 every day to at least make sure most of the many tasks relieved where done. I have never been so stressed at work like I did at oracle. I was able to learn the very difficult and tedious work, the country’s billing was suffering when I started and I managed to show great results within 2 months, pay was decent at the beginning, however; it was definitely not enough when they added so much to the already heavy work load. I asked for a raise and better work conditions. Nothing changed and management wanted to add more and more work no matter what without any extra pay so for my mental, emotional, and physical health and peace I had to quit. I was in charge of handling millions of dollars in billing and I did a great job but it was never really recognized.

review_title: Your success depends on your manager
job_title: Business Development Representative (BDR) in Austin, TX
pros: - Great company to have on your resume - Teammates can be cool - Great remote job - Ok pay unless you have to move to Austin
cons: - If you have a bad manager you're screwed because you'll have very little support - The OTE is 80k: around 50k base and 30k bonus. Hitting 30k is nearly impossible. You have to set about 25-40 meetings per quarter which is extremely difficult. Only 3-5 people from 10 different groups (of 10+ people) achieve this - You're just another piece in the cog - they churn BDRs in and out all year long. Each cohort has 140+ people. You're VERY replaceable. - Even your colleagues are your competition. Very cut throat - Poor communication from higher management to middle management. While I was there, our manager switched our strategy 4+ times, contradicting himself almost every time. Each manager was operating differently.

pros: Oracle has many good organizations, offers career development and challenging work, ability to work from home, good volunteer programs and good benefits.
cons: OCI is a company unto itself, is not representative of Oracle as a whole. The recommendation from someone within is stay away. Leadership is hostile and uses scare and gotcha leadership tactics. Don’t be fooled by the values, they aren’t practicing them. There’s no mentoring, or support from management, in fact Jae Evans creates a hostile work place within the org but if you’ve read up on Clay, poor picks in leadership aren’t a surprise. Management turn over and reorganization is insane so setting up performance goals at the beginning of the year and reviewing with your third manager the end of the year is pointless. And having your fourth manager in a year try to speak to your promotional story while they’re still trying to figure out what you do, how the org is structured this week, and most importantly how they can land grab within the moving landscape, well that doesn’t lend itself to career progression for you, but maybe that’s the point.
